item.title: Cerebras Files Prospectus for I.P.O.
item.description: The Silicon Valley company would be among the first A.I. companies to go public since the release of ChatGPT nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cerebras makes a chip that is 56 times the size of a chip commonly used for artificial intelligence, with the potential to crunch data much faster.

item.title: OpenAI Is Growing Fast and Burning Through Piles of Money
item.description: As the company looks for more outside investors, documents reviewed by The New York Times show consumer fascination with ChatGPT and a serious need for more cash.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The chief executive of OpenAI, Sam Altman, center, is pitching an investment round that could value the start-up at $150 billion.

item.title: Meta’s Race for Your Face, Google’s Hit A.I. Notebook and HatGPT
item.description: Building great A.R. glasses is the hardest problem in consumer technology.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Andrej Sokolow/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images

item.title: G.M. Reaches $1.5 Million Fine After Self-Driving Taxi Accident
item.description: The General Motors subsidiary reached a settlement with the main auto safety regulator after one of its self-driving taxis struck a pedestrian in San Francisco last year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Cruise will pay a $1.5 million penalty and face increased oversight of its activities as it restarts testing of its technology.

item.title: Meta Unveils New Instant A.I. Generator
item.description: The tech giant is among the many companies building technology that could remake Hollywood — or help spread disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Mike Isaac

item.title: Can California Regulate A.I.? + Silicon Valley’s Super Babies + System Update!
item.description: “In the United States, we have 50 laboratories of democracy and they’re called states.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Eric Thayer/Associated Press

item.title: OpenAI Adds $4 Billion Credit Line on Top of $6.6 Billion Investment Round
item.description: The San Francisco company is gathering the billions its executives believe they will need to continue building new A.I. technology.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: OpenAI, led by its chief executive, Sam Altman, set up a revolving line of credit with JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Santander, Wells Fargo, SMBC, UBS and HSBC.

item.title: Abuse Claims Add to Telegram C.E.O. Pavel Durov’s Legal Troubles
item.description: The mother of three children with Pavel Durov has poked holes in the Russian tech titan’s carefully managed image through a criminal complaint and her account of their opulent lifestyle.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Clara Watt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Bolgar said she had a romantic relationship with the Telegram founder Pavel Durov for about a decade.

item.title: OpenAI Completes Deal That Values Company at $157 Billion
item.description: The A.I. start-up’s valuation has risen by more than $70 billion in nine months.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: Sam Altman, chief executive officer of OpenAI, spoke in May at a Microsoft event in Seattle. The tech giant is the start-up’s biggest investor.

item.title: Did Apple Just Kill Social Apps?
item.description: Some app makers worry that a subtle change to the iPhone’s contact-sharing permissions could make it hard for them to get the fast growth they need to compete.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose

item.title: Tesla Sales Increase, Suggesting Electric Car Demand Is Rebounding
item.description: The automaker reported a gain of 6.4 percent for the latest quarter, its first such increase this year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Tesla increased sales in part by offering car loans with relatively low interest rates.

item.title: Apple’s A.I. Is Landing Soon on iPhones. Here’s What It’s Like.
item.description: The initial version of Apple Intelligence focuses on helping you with words and photos. Prepare to be impressed and unnerved.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: CRV, a Venture Capital Firm, Will Return Money to Investors
item.description: CRV, based in Silicon Valley, plans to return to investors $275 million because the market for mature start-ups has soured.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four of CRV’s partners, clockwise from rear left: Reid Christian, Murat Bicer, Saar Gur, and Max Gazor at the firm’s office in Palo Alto, Calif.

item.title: Robert Downey Jr. Is a Novelist With a Novel Muse in ‘McNeal’
item.description: The “Oppenheimer” star makes his Broadway debut in Ayad Akhtar’s timely new play about a literary lion who gets assistance from A.I.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: Robert Downey Jr. goes dark in “McNeal,” a thought experiment about art and A.I., at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Verizon Mobile Outages Reported Across the U.S.
item.description: The number of cases peaked at more than 100,000 Monday morning, according to the website Downdetector. Users complained of being unable to make calls or send texts.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Verizon users said their phones were intermittently displaying “SOS” mode and that they could not place calls or send or receive text messages.

item.title: California’s Governor Gavin Newsom Vetoes Sweeping A.I. Legislation
item.description: The bill would have been the first in the nation to place strict guardrails on the new technology, but Gov. Gavin Newsom said the bill was flawed.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said that he had asked technology and legal scholars to work with legislators in writing a new bill.

item.title: California Passes Law Protecting Consumer Brain Data
item.description: The state extended its current personal privacy law to include the neural data increasingly coveted by technology companies.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Moens
item.media:description: A hands-free brain-computer interface device at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

item.title: Why Stellantis, Owner of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram, Is Struggling
item.description: The automaker, created by a 2021 merger, is dealing with labor unrest, slumping sales and a revolt from its dealers.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Tag Christof for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dealers and analysts said Stellantis had moved too slowly to offer incentives as demand for new cars weakened.

item.title: Titan Sub Hearing: What We’ve Learned So Far
item.description: Contrary to public reports last year, the passengers probably had no idea that the vessel was about to implode.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: The Coast Guard released footage from a remotely operated vehicle that it said showed debris of the Titan submersible on the sea floor.

item.title: Hurricanes and Wildfires Are Taxing Utilities. Can A.I. Help?
item.description: From hurricanes to wildfires, a new generation of technologies could help utilities better plan for the risk of extreme weather to their electric grid.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Downed power lines in Crawfordville, Fla., on Friday morning.
